Today students at Paw Paw Early Elementary and Paw Paw Later Elementary learned the names of the two red wolf pup mascots. The name Rufus was chosen for the male pup, and Rosy for the female pup.

The names were submitted as part of a contest for elementary-aged students in Paw Paw schools, and the winners of the contest were Ava Martin at the Later Elementary (pictured with Principal Davison), and Isabella Holbrook and Corbin Anderson at the Early Elementary.

Rufus is the Latin word for "red", and is part of the scientific name of the Red Wolf (Canis rufus). Rosy is of course both a name, and an adjective to describe something as both being reddish in color, but also cheerful and optimistic.

We think these are awesome names to remind our elementary students that they belong to the Paw Paw Red Wolf pack, and that having knowledge (like science), and being cheerful and optimistic are great ways to have success in and out of school.

Thanks to all students who participated, and congratulations to our contest winners.

PAW PAW STUDENTS AND COMMUNITY INVITED TO SUBMIT SUGGESTIONS FOR NEW NICKNAME

The process for selecting a new nickname for Paw Paw Public Schools kicks off today, April 2, and the 27-student Task Force helping to lead the process is inviting anyone (students, alumni, staff, community members, etc.) with a suggestion, idea, or thought for the next nickname to submit it using our online survey.

https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/QLWH9HK

The survey will be open for suggestions from today until April 24 @ Noon, at which time the submission process will be closed. All serious and respectful nickname submissions will then be put on a ballot, and anyone interested in voting to identify the Top 10 choices will be invited to participate in the voting.

Please keep in mind that Paw Paw WILL NOT be changing school colors as part of the process to adopt a new nickname.

Dear Paw Paw Families,

Beginning this week, the free meals for all children 18 and under that Paw Paw Schools is offering can be picked up on Mondays and Thursdays between 11 a.m. and 1 p.m. behind the middle school. This is a change from last week, as we are reducing our pickup days from three days per week to two days per week. We are still providing seven days' worth of meals between these two pickup days. Those unable to leave their home and pick up meals during the scheduled times are welcome to call their school office to request a no-contact delivery.

In addition, we want to share the post below from Bronson Methodist Hospital. If you would like to drop off any donations for Bronson at PPMS while you are picking up meals on Monday or Thursday, we will make sure those donations get delivered.

And finally, we want to encourage everyone to stay informed regarding school-related items by reading the Daily Updates that the District is providing in the News section of our school website, www.ppps.org. Daily Updates are posted at around noon each day, Monday through Friday.

PPPS is making an adjustment to our school calendar in the month of December. Currently, Friday, December 13 is scheduled to be a 1/2 day of school for students, with professional development for staff in the afternoon. We are changing this day to be a full day of professional development for staff. Therefore, there will be no school for students on Friday, December 13.

Recent changes to state law have given schools the option to add professional development time for staff members to their school calendars. We value professional development opportunities as a means for the professional growth of our staff members and the improvement of our schools. On December 13, we are planning to provide training for all our staff members around childhood trauma and its impact on students' behavior and learning. The knowledge we gain from this training will help us all to be better educators and student advocates.

Thank you for your understanding and support for Paw Paw Schools!

post_text: From the Van Buren Conservation District: The VBCD would like to encourage you to remind residents to properly dispose of tires, which are historically known to be mosquito breeding grounds. The best time to manage used/old tires is to pay the small fee and allow your maintenance garages/licensed businesses to keep your old tires when you get new tires put on (whether it be passenger car tires or tractor tires). Old and used tires should not be stacked in sheds, garages, barns, or on the back 40, the chance they will be used again is statistically low. Ones that are used for exercise/training should be emptied out on a regular basis. We are done with this year’s Scrap Tire Collection opportunities but will have another six collections in 2020, in the meantime tires can be taken to Deer Path Recyclers (56625 Woodhouse Dr. Dowagiac, MI), residents can call, 269-782-7232, for prices and hours of operation. But again, the best way to keep up with used tires is to allow properly licensed businesses to keep them when you get new ones put on!
